description:
Crossoptilon mantchuricum, commonly known as the Manchurian pheasant or Manchurian eared pheasant, is a species of pheasant endemic to northeastern China. It belongs to the genus Crossoptilon, which are eared pheasants.

The Manchurian pheasant is a large, long-tailed pheasant with distinctive long ear-like tufts of feathers on the head. The plumage is predominantly bluish-grey with white underparts and a distinctive white rump and tail. Males and females are similar in appearance, although males tend to be slightly larger.

This species inhabits temperate coniferous and mixed forests, as well as alpine meadows, in the mountains of northeastern China. They feed on a variety of plant matter, including seeds, berries, and green vegetation.

Crossoptilon mantchuricum is considered a vulnerable species due to habitat loss and hunting pressure. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this unique pheasant species and its fragile mountain ecosystem.
